Lab Information ______________________________________________ This manual contains the laboratory material for students enrolled in the two-semester course of Human Anatomy & Physiology (Biol 2401/2402). The manual is divided into two major sections: (1) the listings of the anatomical structures that students will learn, and (2) the keys to the laboratory charts and models. Because the Biology Department continuously purchases new models, some keys may not be included in this edition. However, keys that are not in this edition can be downloaded from the Anatomy & Physiology Lab page on Desire2Learn (D2L). Desire2Learn (D2L) Every student enrolled in Biol 2401/2402 should have access to the lab page on D2L. This page contains important announcements, tutoring hours, new keys to models, and various links to animations. All students should be added to the D2L A&P Lab page at the beginning of the semester. If a student does not have access after the first week of class, the instructor should be notified. Lab Models The lab models are to remain in the lab at all times. Under no circumstances can lab models be removed from the lab. The models are expensive and should be respected (some bones, for example, are real). Any student who damages a model intentionally will be immediately removed from the course and will be required to pay the cost to replace the model. Students should also make a habit of using the wooden pointers available in the lab instead of pens and pencils to point to structures on all models. Tutoring and Tutoring Policies Instructors realize that the successful study of A&P requires a significant amount of time. To accommodate the need for additional lab time, tutors are hired to work in the anatomy lab on weekends (and sometimes during one or two weeknights) when funding is available. These tutors are former/current TC students that have successfully completed A&P. They are not expected to “teach” anatomy. Instead, their primary role is to open the lab so students have access to it on weekends when instructors may not be available. Students should not expect a tutor to know everything – but the tutor can certainly help students find the structures on models using the keys and give study hints for exams. Cranial Nerve Foramen or Fissure Function(s) Olfactory nerve (I) Olfactory foramina of Cribiform plate Sensory: for special sense of smell Optic nerve (II) Optic foramen Sensory: for special sense of vision Oculomotor nerve (III) Superior orbital fissure Motor: to eye muscles (superior, medial, and inferior rectus; inferior oblique) and upper eyelid (levator palpebra superiosis) Parasympathetic: to sphincter pupillae (pupil constriction) and the ciliary muscle of the lens (causing accommodation) Trochlear nerve (IV) Superior orbital fissure Motor: to an eye muscle (superior oblique) Trigeminal nerve (V) Ophthalmic branch Superior orbital fissure Sensory: from scalp, forehead, nose, upper eyelid, and cornea Maxillary branch Foramen rotundum Sensory: from palate, upper jaw, upper teeth and gums, nasopharynx, nasal cavity, skin, mucous membranes of cheek, lower eyelid, and upper lip Cranial Nerve Foramen or Fissure Function(s) Trigeminal Nerve Continued Mandibular branch Foramen ovale Sensory: from lower jaw, lower teeth and gums, anterior 2/3 of tongue, mucous membrane of cheek, lower lip, skin of cheek and chin, auricle, and temporal region Motor: to mastification muscles (masseter, temporalis, medial and lateral pterygoids), soft palate, throat, and middle ear (tensor tympani) Abducens nerve (VI) Superior orbital fissure Motor: to an eye muscle (lateral rectus) Facial nerve (VII) Internal auditory meatus & Sensory: Stylomastoid foramen to special sense of taste on anterior 2/3 of tongue Motor: to facial muscles, throat (posterior belly of digastric, stylohyoid) and middle ear (stapedius) Parasympathetic: to submandibular and sublingual salivary glands, lacrimal gland, and glands in nasal cavity and palate Vestibulocochlear nerve Internal acoustic meatus Sensory: (VIII) for special sense of hearing and balance Cranial Nerve Foramen or Fissure Function(s) Glossopharyngeal (IX) Jugular foramen Sensory: for special sense of taste on posterior 1/3 of tongue; sensory from pharynx, palatine tonsils, posterior 1/3 of tongue, middle ear, carotid sinus, and carotid body Motor: to pharyngeal muscle (stylopharyngeus) Parasympathetic: to parotid salivary gland, glands of posterior 1/3 of tongue Vagus nerve (X) Jugular foramen Sensory: from inferior pharynx, larynx, thoracic and abdominal organs, special sense of taste from posterior tongue Motor: to soft palate, pharynx, intrinsic laryngeal muscles (voice producing muscles), and an extrinsic tongue muscle Parasympathetic: to thoracic and abdominal viscera Accessory nerve (XI) Foramen magnum; jugular Motor: foramen to sternocleidomastoid and trapezius Hypoglossal nerve (XII) Hypoglossal canal Motor: to intrinsic and extrinsic tongue muscles and throat muscles NOTES SPECIAL SENSES I.
